# Transitional Kindergarten (TK) Expansion 2025-26

## Universal TK Achieved!

As of the 2025-26 school year, California achieved **universal Transitional Kindergarten** for all four-year-old children.

## Who is Eligible?

All children who turn 4 by **September 1** of the school year they enroll.

### 2025-26 School Year
- **Eligible:** Children born on or before September 1, 2021
- **All 4-year-olds** now have access regardless of:
  - Income level
  - Immigration status
  - Zip code
  - Background

## Key Features

### Free Public Education
- **No cost to families**
- Part of California's public school system
- Available at all public school districts

### Program Standards
- **Staff ratio:** 1:12 (adult to student) in 2024-25
- **Moving to 1:10** ratio (additional aide in each classroom)
- Developmentally appropriate curriculum
- Credentialed teachers + paraprofessional

## TK vs Preschool

| Feature | TK | State Preschool |
|---------|-----|----------------|
| Age | 4 by Sept 1 | 3-4 years |
| Cost | Free | Free if income-eligible |
| Location | Public schools | Various sites |
| Hours | School day (~6 hrs) | Varies |
| Calendar | School year | Year-round possible |
| Eligibility | Universal | Income-based |

## State Investment

- **$1.4 billion** ongoing funding (2024-25)
- **$876 million** additional for full expansion (2025-26)
- **$952 million** proposed for improved 1:10 ratio

## What This Means for Families

### If Your Child Turns 4 by September 1:
- Automatically eligible for TK
- Enroll through your local school district
- Free full-day program available

### You Still Have Choices
- Can choose CSPP or Head Start instead if eligible
- Can choose private preschool
- TK is an option, not mandatory

## Enrollment Process

1. Contact your local school district
2. Complete enrollment forms (similar to kindergarten)
3. Provide:
   - Proof of child's age (birth certificate)
   - Proof of residency
   - Immunization records
4. Attend registration/orientation

## Extended Learning

Many districts offer:
- **Expanded TK:** Extended hours beyond school day
- **Before/after care:** Additional supervision
- **Summer programs:** Continued learning

## Impact on Child Care Subsidies

- TK is free, so no subsidy needed for TK hours
- May still need subsidized care for:
  - Before/after school
  - Summer
  - Days TK is not in session

**More Info:** https://www.cde.ca.gov/ci/gs/em/kinderfaq.asp
